item.term: Early first millennium to the fourth century BC (predominance of Saba)
Fourth to first centuries BC (predominance of Qataban and Hadramawt, and their alliance with Main)
First century BC to early second century AD (alliances between the tribes of the high plateau and the ASA kingdoms)
Late second to late third centuries AD (wars among the Himyar, Saba and Hadramawt)
Fourth to sixth centuries AD (unification of Yemen under Himyarite rule)

Restored full text of the inscription:
1.[Wadadʾīl Raymān bin ʾAbīkarib, of the lineage of Ṣabaḥrām Dhū-Khalīl.] 2.[Biʿathtar bin Wadadʾīl, of the lineage of Ṣabaḥrām Dhū-Khalīl, (had this inscription carved) when he served as priest of (the god) ʿAthtar,] 3.[and he (i.e. ʿAthtar) absolved him of his duties with respect to all of his temples. And ʿAthtar provided irrigation during the autumn and spring, during his priesthood,] 4.since he settled in (the town of) [Nashqum.] 5.ʿAmmīkarib bin Wa[dadʾīl, of the lineage of Ṣabaḥrām Dhū-Khalīl, (had this inscription carved)] 6.[whe]n he served as priest of ʿAt[htar. And he (i.e. ʿAthtar) absolved him of his duties with respect to all of] his 7.[templ]es. And ʿAth[tar] provided irrigation [for Sabaʾ and the community] 8.during the autumn and spring.

Restored full text of the inscription:
Wadadʾīl Raymān bin ʾAbīkarib, of the lineage of Ṣabaḥrām Dhū-Khalīl.
Biʿathtar bin Wadadʾīl, of the lineage of Ṣabaḥrām Dhū-Khalīl, had this inscription carved when he served as priest of the god ʿAthtar,
and he i.e. ʿAthtar absolved him of his duties with respect to all of his temples. And ʿAthtar provided irrigation during the autumn and spring, during his priesthood,
since he settled in the town of Nashqum.
ʿAmmīkarib bin Wadadʾīl, of the lineage of Ṣabaḥrām Dhū-Khalīl, had this inscription carved

temples. And ʿAthtar provided irrigation for Sabaʾ and the community
during the autumn and spring.
